keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, 38, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five and life in prison by a Utah district judge.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities later questioned.
He was arrested in Scotland in 2023 while receiving treatment for COVID-19, identified by distinctive tattoos, including a Brown University crest, linked to an Interpol notice.
Rossi used at least a dozen aliases over the years to evade capture, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight.
The victim described the trauma of the rape and the long-term emotional damage, emphasizing a plea for safety, accountability, and recognition of lasting harm.
Rossi’s defense argued that he was falsely accused, but the jury found him guilty in both trials, and he did not testify during the proceedings.
He is considered a ‘serial abuser of women’ and a ‘flight risk’ by prosecutors, and Utah law allows for a sentence range of five years to life for first-degree rape.
Rossi fled to avoid arrest after being identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit, and was only brought back through a protracted extradition process.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, 38, a man with a history of sexual abuse and multiple aliases, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit in 2018, he allegedly faked his death in 2020 with a false obituary, evading authorities for years. He was arrested in Scotland in 2023 based on a distinctive tattoo and an Interpol notice, and extradited to Utah in January 2024. He pleaded not guilty and maintained his innocence during the trial, but was found guilty by a jury. A Utah judge sentenced him to between five and life in prison, citing his status as a flight risk and serial abuser. The case highlights the dangers of rape kit backlogs, the use of aliases to evade justice, and the importance of international cooperation in tracking fugitives. The victims emphasized the long-term emotional trauma and a need for accountability and safety in the face of abuse.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
